Evidence: "In all markets and all industries, disruption is pervasive... one in three companies will cease to exist in 5 years, up from one in twenty 50 years ago."
"Seventy-five percent of major transformation efforts do not achieve their expectations for target value, timing, or both."
Report synthesizes five critical elements: (1) clear-eyed diagnosis, (2) redefine strategic focus, (3) restructure to cut cost/complexity, (4) build right culture, (5) invest in digital.
"Strong leaders get ahead of the problem with an ambitious program to change the company’s trajectory… 'If it ain’t broken, fix it anyway.'"
"Leaders need to determine where to play (and where to avoid)… and take action to divest and to acquire and/or invest in new businesses or R&D."
"Turnaround programs require rapid improvements in operations to reduce costs, and they almost always entail changes to the organization and/or operating model."
"Turnarounds require speed, innovation, and a culture of openness to change."

"Even if a company doesn’t think digital is a part of the turnaround strategy, it needs to be… invest in digital technology to improve customer experience, enhance products, increase efficiency, and develop new business models."
"Margins of these companies have increased by a weighted average of more than 50% since 2013… they have outperformed the S&P Global 1200 by 46 percentage points."
HSBC operated in 88 countries with many standalone entities and separate IT systems, leading to a complex operating environment and few economies of scale.
Under the new CEO, HSBC reduced headcount by more than 20% and cut the number of countries from 88 to 67, saving $4.7B by 2016 and an expected $6B by 2017.
HSBC reduced risk-weighted assets by nearly $300 billion, improving capital performance during the turnaround.
HSBC restructured into four global businesses each led by executives reporting directly to the CEO, supported by globally run support functions, enabling economies of scale.
The bank invested $2.1 billion in digital from 2015 to 2020, including automation, mobile customer journeys, analytics, and a Google Cloud partnership.
HSBC is described as a top financial services performer in dividend payouts, with a 42% increase since the turnaround began and $5.5B in share buybacks announced.
Most of the $4.7–6B savings came from middle- and back-office functions, indicating focus on support-process efficiency.
BMS lost patent exclusivity for Pravachol (sales down $1.2B in one year) and saw a 15% decline in Plavix sales, losing another $1.5B.
Instead of megamergers, BMS chose to transform from a diversified health care company into a biopharma pure play by reshaping its business and R&D portfolios.
In 2007 BMS launched a productivity program that took $2.5B out of the business over five years, largely from SG&A, to fund the new strategy.
BMS closed diagnostics, sold wound care in 2008, and spun off nutritionals in a 2009 IPO to concentrate on biopharma.
BMS chose immuno-oncology as a key therapeutic area; I-O sales grew from 0% to 25% of total and are expected to exceed 50% by 2021, with Opdivo reaching $3.8B in 2016 and projected $8–9B by 2020.
R&D was repositioned as a decision-making hub to make tradeoffs across the pipeline rather than just originator of drugs, including revamped governance committees and 'follow the science' incentives.
BMS seeks external partners such as university labs and startups to access promising new drug approaches.
Over six years, BMS’s total shareholder return outpaced peers by ~5 percentage points per year; revenue rose 18% and EBITDA margins 15%, with market cap nearly doubling.
Boston Scientific’s $27B acquisition of Guidant required absorbing cost, integrating quality systems, and establishing a new culture.
Company revamped its portfolio via acquisitions to emphasize stronger growth and category leadership, e.g., reinforcing leadership in urology.
Boston Scientific expanded into China and Brazil; share of sales from emerging markets doubled since 2013.
The company created manufacturing centers of excellence using lean and new technologies to reduce manufacturing costs and improve processes.
R&D as a percentage of revenue declined by 10% while the firm continued to launch innovative products.
Leaders thinned bureaucracy to speed decisions and launched programs empowering teams to propose unconventional solutions; best projects receive funding and recognition.
Revenue is up nearly 20% since 2013 and EBIT margins are up 30%; market capitalization nearly quintupled in the period.
"Just five years later… Nokia’s market capitalization had dropped 96%… operating losses more than $2B in first half of 2012."
Nokia sold its mobile-phone business to Microsoft in a $7.2B deal in 2013 as part of a bet-the-company turnaround.
Post-divestment, Nokia focused on networks, mapping, and patent licensing; it bought out Siemens’ share of the network JV and made it the new core.
Nokia’s $16.6B acquisition of Alcatel-Lucent expanded it to a full-service network infrastructure provider and strengthened its North American presence.
Nokia sold its mapping business to a consortium of German carmakers for $3B to sharpen strategic focus.
Patent and technology licensing accounted for <5% of revenue but 22% of operating profits in 2016 and a higher share of valuation.
Company turned over 99% of employee base, 80% of the board, and all but one executive since the turnaround began.
Nokia’s market capitalization grew more than 500% between the low point in 2012 and 2017.
UPM’s core graphic paper segment faced demand declines averaging 5% per year in Europe and North America from 2006–2012.
From 2006–2009 UPM closed about 14% of paper capacity and acquired a competitor, generating ~$240M in annual cost synergies.
In 2013 UPM launched further cost cuts: closing more paper facilities, reducing headcount, and selling forest properties.
UPM reorganized into six businesses: European/North American paper, specialty paper, plywood, labels, biorefining, and energy.
UPM invested about $730M in growth projects, including a specialty paper plant in China and a wood-based renewable diesel biofuels facility in Finland.
Share of revenue from declining paper markets fell from ~70% in 2006 to below 50% in 2016.
Annual patent applications increased by 280% since 2008 as part of a push for innovation.
More decision-making authority was pushed down to business units to increase nimbleness and responsiveness.
From 2008–2016, employee engagement rose 20 percentage points, sales per employee increased 34%, and time lost to accidents declined 83%.
All wood is sustainably sourced, wastewater reduced, and UPM appears on multiple sustainability indices.
Despite scaling back paper, UPM maintained consistent revenue while profit margins and share price rose sharply (share price +212%, margins +61% over period).
Groupe PSA relied on Europe for more than two-thirds of sales as the regional market plunged post–financial crisis.
PSA had 23 Peugeot and 22 Citroën models that were insufficiently differentiated and cannibalized demand, with lower pricing and higher labor costs than peers.
The company lost $5.4B in 2012 and $2.5B in 2013, prompting a recapitalization with Dongfeng and the French government (each buying 14% stakes).
PSA differentiated brands—Citroën as value, Peugeot mid-market, DS as premium—to regain pricing power and rationalize discounts.
PSA planned to thin its model range from 45 to 26 by 2022, significantly simplifying its product portfolio.

Later case studies (Olympus, Ajinomoto, Lanxess, Qantas, Acciona) are referenced in the table of contents but their full narrative content is truncated in the parsed text, preventing reliable concept extraction.
